Requested by Pembina Homemakers

What did early Canadian pioneers eat?

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and will it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. Albert T. Calburn
Address: P.A.M.B.R.U.M., SASK.
Birthplace: Villiersdale, Nova Scotia

1. Introductory Questions
   What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1929
   Where did you get your housekeeping? Self-taught
   Where had you been living before that? Nelson, British Columbia
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
   How far was it to your nearest store? 40 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Occasionally
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Sugar, tea, coffee, salt, beans, soda & cream of tartar, oatmeal

2. Flour and Other Grain Products
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Willard's Best
   In what quantities did you buy it? 98 lbs
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.50
   How much did you use Graham flour? ...........................................
   Whole wheat flour? ...............................................................
   Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? 71, what year? 1909
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.65
   What other grain products did you use? ........................................
   Cornmeal? .................................. Whole wheat? ............... Farine? ..............
   Oats? ........................................ Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes
   How did you grind it? With a grinder

Miss A.B. BEA T. BALDWIN,
P.A.M.B.KUN., SASK.,
North Dakota, Willmar, Minnesota.

1. What year did you start homesteading in North Dakota? 1909.

2. What brand of wheat flour did you use in early years? Red Star.

3. In what quantities did you buy flour? 100 lbs.

4. How much did you pay per hundred pounds of flour? $8.50.

5. Was there any other product you used? Yes, cornmeal.

6. Did you grow your own wheat for personal use? Yes.

7. How did you travel? By horseback.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 25 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $5.00.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers Golden Syrup.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 oz.

At what price? $6.00.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Cow.

Butter? Made own.

Eggs? Had hens.

What was the price of butter? $2.50.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Cottage Cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Cured meat.

How did you get fresh meat? Did without.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? Brine.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Pheasant, Pheasant Chicken.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? Could not procure fresh.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

Kinds? Salmon, Hardines.

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Both

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ashes?

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Buffalo Chips

Where did you get your fuel? From the Prairie

Lignite or Salt Coal

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

About 1917 we used kerosene stoves then Caroline & at present using Propane Gas

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Porridge. Tea. Bread. Butter. Eggs

18. What was served for your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Thanksgiving Dinner. Turkey, vegetables, pickles, cranberry sauce.

Mr. & Mrs. Colburn. about 34 & 35.
